choices.A: An equal amount of time on analysis, design, programming, testing and documentation.
choices.D: As much as it can fit into the Sprint. Any remaining work will be moved to a subsequent Sprint.
choices.B: As much as it has informed the Product Owner will be done for every Product Backlog item it selects in conformance with the definition of ג€Doneג€.
choices.C: All development work and at least some testing.

questions.question_text: How much work must a Development Team do to a Product Backlog item it selects for a Sprint?

choices.B: Do all of the development work in order to handoff to the testers in the subsequent Sprint.
choices.C: Complete the project within the estimate as committed to the Product Owner.
choices.A: Turn the Product Backlog items it selects into a potentially releasable product increment of functionality.

questions.question_text: The Development Team should have all the skills and competencies needed to:

choices.A: Frequently in order to share knowledge.
choices.B: As needed, while taking into account a short term reduction in productivity.
choices.C: Never, as it conflicts with the Scrum process.
choices.D: As needed, as long as it doesn't impact productivity.

questions.answer_description: It is not mandatory that the same team stay together, although it must be understood that any changes to the team will impact how they work together.
questions.question_text: How often should Development Team membership change?

choices.A: Writing User Stories and ordering the Product Backlog.
choices.C: Organizing the work required to meet the Sprint Goal and resolving internal team conflicts.
choices.B: Reporting productivity and selecting the Sprint time-box.

questions.question_text: What is the Development Team responsible for?
What is the recommended size for a Development Team (within the Scrum Team)?
